error.signature: Error response from daemon: remove volume: volume is in use
error.regex: volume.*in use|remove.*volume.*in use|unable to remove volume

verdict.summary: A Docker volume cannot be removed because it is currently mounted by one or more containers, including stopped containers.

dead_ends.why_fails: Bypasses Docker's internal state; Docker will still think the volume exists, causing ghost entries and potential data corruption

dead_ends.action: Using docker volume prune while the volume is still referenced
dead_ends.why_fails: Prune only removes unreferenced volumes; volumes attached to stopped containers are still referenced

workarounds.action: Find and remove the containers using the volume first
workarounds.how: docker ps -a --filter volume=<volume-name> to find containers, then docker rm <container-id> for each, then docker volume rm <volume-name>

workarounds.action: Use docker compose down -v to clean up volumes with their compose project
workarounds.how: docker compose down -v removes containers, networks, AND volumes defined in the compose file
workarounds.condition: when volumes were created by Docker Compose

leads_to.condition: when inability to remove volumes leads to disk space exhaustion

preceded_by.condition: when containers using volumes cannot be stopped cleanly

frequently_confused_with.distinction: Volume in use means a storage volume is mounted by a container, while image prune in use means an image layer is referenced by a container or another image
